In our previous episode, we 
looked at the first two steps

necessary when negotiating in English.   
We’ve written a whole blog post about this,

so if you want to read on all the language 
must-haves when negotiating in English,
click on this link up here.

In this video, we’re going to 
move straight on to step number 3.
Making your proposal.

After small talk, and then 
reluctantly opening negotiations,
it is time to tell people what you actually want.

We were hoping to interest you in taking 
1,000 garden gnomes for your range.

To be honest, we don’t have a 
big margin on these products.

However, we would be willing to offer them to you 
at a unit price of £5. What are your thoughts?”

Okay, let's just have a quick look 
at the language that was used:

To be honest - this is language that 
shows that you are being authentic,

vulnerable, transparent, trustworthy.
We would be willing - this language makes

it sound like you’re doing your buyer a favour.
What are your thoughts? Throw them the ball.

You’ve made your proposal, now it’s 
time for them to make the next move.
Step and language must-have number 4
Keep calm.

You’ve made your offer, and you might start 
to worry that what you’ve offered is too

expensive. British negotiators keep calm. Always. 
Because keeping calm influences the language that

you choose to use. So, as a response to your 
proposal, you might hear one of these replies:
The coded speech.
I think they’re worth every penny,

but it might be challenging for us 
to pay that much from our budget.
The understatement.

Interesting, but that price wasn’t 
quite what we were expecting.

Humour, aka the comedian. 
That gnome you’ve brought

with you is looking at me and 
asking me to buy it for £3
The vague approach - aka the philosopher.

I’ve never really thought about how 
much a garden gnome costs to produce.
All four of these responses are saying

the exact same thing. There is no way on earth 
that we are paying £5 for one garden gnome!

And that’s it for this video. I’ve gone 
through steps 3 and 4 of the language

must-haves when negotiating in 
English. If you want to read

all 6, click the link above and it 
will take you to the full article!

I’m glad you’ve stayed till the end of this 
video. Make sure you subscribe because we have

a lot more business English language 
skills that we want to share with you.

If you’re seriously looking to improve 
your Business English language skills,

click on the link in the description and it 
will take you to the English Online website,

where you can have a look at the courses that 
we provide specifically on Business English.

I’ll see you again next time 
for our third and final episode.
